lines.text: [last lines]
Oh no you don't! Osgood, I'm gonna level with you. We can't get married at all.
Why not?
Well, in the first place, I'm not a natural blonde.
Doesn't matter.
I smoke! I smoke all the time!
I don't care.
Well, I have a terrible past. For three years now, I've been living with a saxophone player.
I forgive you.

[tragically]
I can never have children!
We can adopt some.
But you don't understand, Osgood! Ohh...
[Jerry finally gives up and pulls off his wig]

[normal voice]
I'm a man!

[shrugs]
Well, nobody's perfect!
[Jerry looks on with disbelief as Osgood continues smiling with indifference. Fade out]
Have I got things to tell you!
What happened?
I'm engaged.
Congratulations. Who's the lucky girl?
I am!
Syncopators. Does that mean you play that very fast music... jazz?
Yeah. Real Hot.
I guess some like it hot. I personally prefer classical music.
I am Osgood Fielding the third.
I'm Cinderella the second.
[at the booking office, trying to be hired]
What kind of a band is this, anyway?
You gotta be under twenty-five.
We could pass for that.
You gotta be blonde.
We could dye our hair.
And you gotta be girls.
We could...
No, we couldn't!
you're a boy, you're a boy.
I'm a boy.
That's the boy.

[coming around]
I'm a boy. I'm a boy. I wish I were dead. I'm a boy. Boy, oh boy, am I a boy. Now, what am I gonna do about my engagement present?
What engagement present?
Osgood gave me a bracelet.

[takes it and inspects the stones with Beinstock's glasses]
Hey, these are real diamonds!
Of course they're real! What do you think? My fiance is a bum?

[on marrying well]
I don't care how rich he is, as long as he has a yacht, his own private railroad car, and his own toothpaste.

[grabbing Daphne by the collar]
Daphne?
Well, I never did like the name Geraldine.
You're the wrong shape. Goodbye!
What are you looking for - hunchbacks or something?
It's not the backs that worry me.

[referring to his mother]
Right now, she thinks I'm out there on my yacht - deep sea fishing!
Well, pull in your reel, Mr. Fielding, you're barking up the wrong fish!
If my mother could only see me now.
I hope *my* mother never finds out.
But, you're *not* a girl! You're a *guy*, and, why would a guy wanna marry a guy?
Security!
You must be quite a girl.
Wanna bet?
What happened here?

[referring to Spats and his thugs]
There was something in that cake that didn't agree with them.
My compliments to the chef. Nobody leaves this room until I get the recipe.
You wanna make a federal case of it?

[grabs the speaker of Little Bonaparte's hearing aid]
Yeah!
Will you look at that! Look how she moves! It's like Jell-O on springs. Must have some sort of built-in motor or something. I tell you, it's a whole different sex!
Been waiting long?

[gallantly]
It's not how long you wait, it's who you're waiting for!
There's another problem.
Like what?
Like, what are you gonna do on your honeymoon?
We've been discussing that. He wants to go to the Riviera but I kinda lean towards Niagara Falls.
Real diamonds! They must be worth their weight in gold!
Story of my life. I always get the fuzzy end of the lollipop.
Water polo? Isn't that terribly dangerous?
I'll say. I had two ponies drowned under me.
What are you worried about? This job is going to last a long time.
Well, suppose it doesn't?

Jerry, boy, why do you have to paint everything so black? Suppose you got hit by a truck. Suppose the stock market crashes. Suppose Mary Pickford divorces Douglas Fairbanks. Suppose the Dodgers leave Brooklyn!

[Jerry notices the badge of an undercover agent at a nearby table]
Joe...?
Suppose Lake Michigan overflows.
Well, don't look now, but the whole town is underwater!

Idiot broads! Here we are, all packed, ready to leave for Miami, and what happens? The saxophone runs off with a Bible salesman, and the bass fiddle gets herself pregnant! Beinstock, I ought to fire you!
Me? I'm the manager of the band, not the night watchman.

[singing]
I wanna be loved by you, just you, nobody else but you. I wanna be loved by you alo-o-one. Boop boop e doo.
Look, if all you're interested in is whether I am married or not...
Oh, I'm not interested at all.
Well, I'm not.
That's very interesting!
Look, chief, I better blow 'cause if Columbo sees me, it's gonna be "Goodbye Charlie!"
Goodbye, Charlie.

[Joe used a "Cary Grant" voice when posing as a millionaire]
What are you trying to do to that poor girl, putting on a millionaire act? And, where did you get that phony accent? Nobody "talks loike thet"!
In duh lass fissel year we made a hundred an' twelve million dollars before taxes... only we didn't pay no taxes!

[pouring bourbon into paper cup]
Turn the lights on.
No lights, we don't want anyone to know we're having a party.
But I might spill some.
So spill it! Spills, thrills, laughs, and games. This may even turn out to be a surprise party.
What's the surprise?
Not yet.
When?
Better have a drink first.
There. That'll put hair on your chest.
No fair guessing.

[Kissing]
I think you're on the right track.
I must be. Your glasses are beginning to steam up.

[after meeting the all-girl band they'll be traveling with]
How about that talent, huh? It's like falling into a tub of butter.
Watch it, Daphne!

When I was a kid, Joe, I used to have a dream. I was locked up overnight in a pastry shop, and there was goodies all around. There was jelly rolls, and mocha eclairs, and sponge cake and Boston cream pie...
Look, Stoop...
And cherry tart...
Stoop, listen to me! No butter, no pastry. We're on a diet!

[apologizing because the motor boat will only move backwards]
I'm afraid it may take a little longer.
It's not how long it takes, it's who's taking you.
Now you've done it! Now you have done it!
Done what?
You tore off one of my chests!

[when his speakeasy is raided]
What's the rap this time?
Embalming people with coffee - 86 proof.
I come from this musical family. My mother is a piano teacher and my father was a conductor.
Where did he conduct?
On the Baltimore and Ohio.
You know, I've always been *fascinated* by show business.
Is that so?
Yes. As a matter of fact it's cost my family quite a bit of money.
Oh, you invest in shows?
Showgirls. I've been married seven or eight times.
You're not sure?
Mama is keeping score.

[admiring a large fish trophy]
What is it?
It's a member of the herring family.
A herring? Isn't it amazing how they get those big fish into those little glass jars?
They shrink when they're marinated.
We won't breathe a word!
You won't breathe nothin' - not even air.

[to coin-flipping wise guy]
Where did you pick up that cheap trick?
Oh, Daphne, how can I ever repay you?
Oh, I can think of a million things.
[Sugar gets into bed with him]
And that's one of them!
[Jerry sees Joe impersonating a wealthy yachtsman to flirt with Sugar]

[to Joe]
This is my friend Daphne, she's a Vassar girl.
I'm a what?
Or was it Bryn Mawr?

[firmly to Jerry]
I heard a very sad story about a girl that went to Bryn Mawr. She squealed on her roommate... and they found her strangled with her own brazier!
Yes, we've got to be very careful who we choose for a roommate.
We're up the creek and you want to hock the paddle!
Oh Josephine! The most wonderful thing happened!
What?
Guess.
They repealed prohibition?
Oh come now, you can do better than that.
I met one of them.
One of whom?
Shell Oil Junior. He's got millions, he's got glasses, he's got a yacht!
You don't say.
He's not only got a yacht, he's got a bicycle!

[to Daphne]
. What are you afraid of? No-one's asking you to have a baby!

[to Sugar]
The ship is in ship-shape shape.

[examining a golf bag]
What's in here?
My golf clubs. The putter, niblick, number three iron...

[pulling out a Tommy sub-machine gun]
What's this?
My mashie!

[to the elevator operator]
All right, driver, once around the park, slowly, and keep your eyes on the road.
You better bring a check in case the joint is raided.
Who's gonna raid a funeral?
Some people got no respect for the dead.
Oh, why did I let you talk me into this?
I thought you weren't speaking to me.

[referring to Jerry]
He has an empty stomach and it's gone to his head.
Hello, copper. What brings you to Miami?
Heard you "opera lovers" were having a convention, so I thought I'd better be around in case anybody decided to sing.
Are you two from the Poliakoff agency?
Yes, we're the new girls.
Brand new!
So you got pinched in the elevator, so what? Would you rather be picking lead out of your navel?

[on the yacht Junior's pretending he owns]
Which is the port and which is the starboard?

Well that depends. That depends on whether you're coming or going. I mean, *normally*, normally, the aft is on the other side of the stern. But - And that's the bridge, so you can get from one side of the boat to the other.

[after running back to the room to tell Josephine about the millionaire, Joe's other alter ego, and finding she's not there]
Well I'll be back later.
Oh no you wait. I have a feeling she'll show up any minute.
Believe it or not, Josephine predicted the whole thing.
Yeah, this is one for Ripley.
Do you suppose she went shopping?
Shopping! That's it! Something tells me she's gonna come through that door in a brand new outfit!
Don't fight it.
It's me, Sugar!

[in the berth, with the lady band members passing food around and a corkscrew's been brought]
Girls, keep it down! You'll wake up the neighbours downstairs, now Josephine... WATCH THAT CORKSCREW!

[to Spats, about the murders they just witnessed]
We didn't see anything. Did we?
No!
[laughs nervously]
Nothing. Besides, it's none of our business if you guys wanna bump each other off, we don't -
[Joe nudges him to shut him up]
I feel a funny sensation in my toes. Like someone is barbecuing them over a fire.
I never knew it could be like this!
Thank you.
They told me I was kaput, finished, all washed up. And here you are making a chump out of all those experts.
Mineral baths, now really!
Where did you learn to kiss like that?
I used to sell kisses for the milk fund.
You shave with your spats on?
I sleep with my spats on.
[Jerry and Joe are in the elevator with Spats and his goons]
Excuse me, ain't I had the pleasure of meetin' you two broads before?
Oh, no. You must be thinking of two other broads.

[as Daphne falls up the train steps]
. Whoops-a-daisy!
[smacks his bottom]
Fresh!
We didn't see anything!
We didn't hear anything either!
[first lines]
All right, Charlie; that the joint?
Yes, sir.
Who runs it?
I already told you.
Refresh my memory.
Spats Columbo.
That's very refreshing; what's the password?
"I've come to Grandma's funeral." Here's your admission card.
[he gives Mulligan a mourning armband]
Thanks, Charlie.
Now if you want a ringside table, just tell 'em that you're one of the pallbearers.
OK, Charlie.

[after meeting the dipsomaniac Sugar]
How about the shape of that liquor cabinet?

[wipes away Sugar's tears]
None of that, Sugar. No guy is worth it.
Alright Spats, services are over, lets go
Go where?
A little country club we run for retired bootleggers. I'm puttin your name up for membership
I dont join nothin'
Ahh... you'll like it there, I'll get the prison tailor to fit you with a pair of special spats - striped!
Big joke!
